theText: --'Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC777 Wednesday, 31 May 1995 1995 Consideration resumed from 29 March. Second Reading Dr THEOPHANOUS (Calwell-Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health) (10.01 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill makes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992, and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. The bill also makes minor technical amendments to a number of acts, as set out in schedule 2 of the bill. An important element of the government's child-care policy is the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate. Introduced in July 1994, this cash payment helps offset child-care expenses for children while both parents are, or the sole parent is, working, studying, training or looking for work. Parents who are using child care for any of these work-related purposes can claim a rebate on the cost of formal child-care services, such as centre based long day care and family day care, or informal child care, such as care provided by nannies and baby-sitters. The child-care cash rebate is administered by the Health Insurance Commission-Medicare. The introduction of the child-care cash rebate recognises the fact that the cost of the child care is a legitimate work expense for parents in the labour force. It has improved the affordability of child care for many working parents. . This bill includes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 to ensure consistency with the intentions of the scheme. The first group of amendments provide hardship provisions to assist certain groups of persons who are currently precluded from receiving the rebate but who should be entitled to the rebate. These groups are: children over the age of 13 years who have a disability or other specified special need which requires ongoing child care; parents who should be considered to have work-related commitments, such as those who are eligible for, but not in receipt of, a carer pension; and families in which one parent has a work-related commitment, but the other parent is unable to work or look after their children due to extenuating circumstances, such as a medical condition. An amendment is sought to allow carers under the age of 18 years who have specified formal child-care qualifications to register under the scheme. Further amendments are proposed to confirm in legislation that family registration is able to be backdated to the date at which the family was first eligible to register, and that the rebate can be paid when a child is absent from child care for specified reasons.

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Jenkins) Took The Chair At 10.00 A.m.
theText: MC778 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 Finally, there are some administrative amendments proposed to rectify a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen, and to make consequential amendments to the act to bring it in line with changes to other Commonwealth legislation. These include amendments to allow the suspension of family and carer registrations if cancellation of registration is being considered. This will avoid unnecessary recoveries by government, while ensuring that individuals maintain their right to appeal against long-term decisions. Other administrative amendments are proposed to: allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the date at which they were first eligible to register; cancel family or carer registrations and recover payments when an administrative error has been made; ensure that the rebate is not paid for child-care expenses which have been, or will be, reimbursed by another agent such as an employer; clarify the eligibility of persons who are not Australian citizens by correcting the description of visa categories to bring the act into line with changes in the Migration Act; broaden the nature of courses which overseas students can be undertaking in order to be eligible for the rebate; allow the managing director of the Health Insurance Commission to delegate powers; allow the minister to have some discretion over receipting requirements; and remove technical defects in the original act. Most of the proposed amendments will be retrospective back to the introduction of the rebate on 1 July 1994, so as to provide maximum assistance to families who should have been entitled to the rebate. Whilst the financial impact of these amendments will be minimal, they serve to strengthen the original intention of the act and to clarify and facilitate certain procedural aspects of the child-care cash rebate scheme. The amendments proposed to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are designed to correct a number of minor drafting errors in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994, which established the professional services review scheme. In addition, the amendments will allow the appointment as a president of a professional services review tribunal of a person who holds or has held judicial office in a state or territory jurisdiction. Professional services review tribunals consider requests from affected practitioners for a review of a determination of a penalty-which may include the disqualification from Medicare-following a finding by a professional services review committee that the practitioner has engaged in inappropriate practice. It was not realised at the time the legislation was drafted that section 21 of the Acts Interpretation Act specifies that a reference in any act to the word 'office' shall be construed as a reference to an office in or for the Commonwealth. The proposed amendment corrects this oversight, which has limited significantly the number of persons who can be considered for appointment as a tribunal president. The proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 are designed to correct a deficiency in the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994. That act, which gave the Health Insurance Commission the power to investigate fraud under Medicare and to deal directly with the Director of Public Prosecutions, does not allow the Health Insurance Commission to retain evidential material seized under the authority of a Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC779 search warrant for more than 60 days unless proceedings for an offence to which that material may afford evidence is instituted within that period. Although the powers of investigation legislation is modelled in large part on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has pointed out that the provision relating to the retention of seized material was based on a similar provision in an early version of the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill 1994. That latter provision was subsequently altered to allow the retention of evidential material until the reason for its seizure no longer exists or it is decided that it is not to be used in evidence. The proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act provide for the retention of such material in similar circumstances. The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that, without the proposed amendments, the commission's search warrant powers are effectively unusable-not a desirable situation. The bill also empowers the Health Insurance Commission to engage in hedging of investment transactions, provide consulting, management and related services and .exercise its powers and perform its functions overseas. The commission has undertaken a number of consultancies primarily, but not exclusively, under the auspices of the World Bank. As these activities are expanding, and moving beyond the use of spare capacity in the commission's operations, it is desirable to make explicit provision to cover this activity. The Health Insurance Commission is an Australian organisation at the forefront of international best practice in the performance of its various functions. Its expertise is recognised both within Australia and internationally. The commission is in a position to perform a flagship role for Australia in areas attracting growing international attention. So far as the proposed hedging power is concerned, this is consistent with other Commonwealth legislation and has been addressed, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, to resolve any doubt about the commission's ability to enter into hedging transactions. Hedging is, of course, one of the tools necessary in a prudent and balanced investment program which includes some overseas investments. The commission operates Medibank Private in competition with other private insurers and must have available to it the same opportunities to manage the funds vested in it by its members. This bill also contains amendments to parts of the National Health Act 1953 which regulate the administration of nursing homes. The government has decided that these amendments should not await the introduction of the new Aged Care Act. The amendments to the current legislation are essential to address two immediate concerns that have been identified. The first concern relates to the complexities of the current payment system. The second concern relates to nursing homes which are able to charge increased fees to their residents and yet fail to provide the basic standard of nursing and personal care. The first concern is addressed by a series of minor amendments that relate to the simplification of the nursing home payment system. Many of the criticisms of the administration of this program relate to the complexity of the current system. Both the November 1994 report of the Senate Community Affairs Reference Committee on the validation of CAM and SAM funding of nursing homes and the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 19: 1994-95 Efficiency audit-validation of nursing home funding acknowledge the complexities of the current system and have identified problems which have arisen as a direct result of these complexities. For example, the Auditor-General has identified problems MC 780 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 in the delivery of appropriate information to nursing home proprietors relating to the Commonwealth's requirements for the payment of benefits. As these simplification measures can be legally achieved by changes to subordinate legislation-that is, the nursing homes financial arrangements principles, a disallowable instrument-it is proposed to proceed down this path. This would allow simplification to proceed quickly and therefore result in a clear and demonstrable response to one of the concerns of the Auditor-General. The introduction of these simplification measures will not result in any change in the entitlement of nursing home proprietors to Commonwealth benefits. These measures will not result in any change to the level of advances paid to nursing home proprietors. The simplification measures will make it easier for a nursing home proprietor to see how the level of Commonwealth benefit was calculated. The current daily calculation of 'loadings', under or over expenditure of amounts paid for nursing and personal care, and OCRE, other cost reimbursed expenditure, will cease and these amounts will be included in the level of advance payment on a monthly basis. These amounts will no longer form part of the 'scale of fees' determined under subsection 40AA(6) but will be included in calculation of the 'notional scale of fees' determined under section 46D of the act. The amendments to sections 40AD, 40ADA and 51A of the act are consequential to the above simplification measures. These amendments will preserve the right of a nursing home proprietor to seek a 'merits review' of the decision as to how much Commonwealth benefit is advanced under section 51A. An aggrieved nursing home proprietor will continue to be able to seek the referral of an appeal to the Nursing Homes Fees Review Committee of Inquiry of a decision on the level of Commonwealth benefit paid under section 51A. The retention of a right of 'merits review' is essential to ensure that unnecessary and costly appeals to the courts are circumvented. The second concern is addressed by a series of minor amendments that relate to nursing homes which have been granted 'exempt bed status.' Recent newspaper reports relating to the compliance of nursing homes with the standards made under section 45D of the act have highlighted an anomaly in the current legislation. The anomaly is that the current provisions of the act do not enable the revocation or suspension of 'exempt bed status' for those nursing homes which have failed to satisfy the standards for nursing home care. The anomaly must be immediately addressed and the amendments contained in the bill will overcome this concern. The granting of an 'exempt bed status' under section 39AB of the act enables a proprietor to charge additional fees to nursing home patients. One of the criteria for granting 'exempt bed status' is that the nursing home provides a higher level of accommodation and services than are normally available at a nursing home. It is clearly incongruous to continue to allow a nursing home to charge additional amounts for a supposed increased level of accommodation and services, when the level of nursing and personal care fails to meet the basic standards. The amendments contained in this bill provide the power to suspend or revoke the 'exempt bed status' of a nursing home where there is a declaration in force, under subsection 45E(l), that the nursing home does not satisfy the standards determined under section 45D of the act. The amendments make it clear that while the 'exempt bed status'of a nursing home is suspended, or revoked, a proprietor will be unable to charge the increased level of fees that would otherwise be payable by the nursing homes' patients. Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 781 It should be noted that the exercise of this new power will only occur where there are serious breaches of the section 45D standards. The decision to suspend the 'exempt bed status' of a nursing home wiil be made where there is some prospect of the standards being reached within a short period of time' and where both the nursing home proprietor and management show a commitment to taking remedial action. The decision to revoke the 'exempt bed status' of a nursing home will be made where the nursing home proprietor' or management fail to show a commitment to taking appropriate action within a reasonable time frame. Where there is little prospect of standards being reached within a reasonable period of time, then the current power, in section 44 of the act, will be used to revoke the approval of the nursing home altogether. The decision to suspend or revoke 'exempt bed status' is to be subject to internal review, as well, as review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The proposed amendment to the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 is to specify directly the health ministers to be consulted by the minister before appointing the chairperson of the council, the chairperson of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a principal committee of the council, and the member of the Australian Health Ethics Committee classified as a person with knowledge of the ethics of medical research. Currently, the act provides that the minister is to consult in relation to these appointments with other members of the Australian Health Ministers Conference. The composition of that membership can of course vary from time to time and currently includes the New Zealand minister, for health. The proposed amendment would specify ,that it is the health minister of each state and territory who is.to be consulted in relation to the appointments . . I now tum to the amendments made to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. One of the principal purposes of these amendments is to establish the basis for a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian register of therapeutic goods and to provide better definition toÂ· some poorly understood aspects Â·of the national regulatory scheme for therapeutic goods which have been identified in its first four years of operation. A mechanism to address shortages or the absence of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has also been included in the bill. Amendments that update and consolidate the entry, search and warrant powers in the new part of the act have also been included,. together with changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the 'penalty units' classifications used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation. The bill also closes a gap within the current regulatory scheme, by which legal therapeutic goods of unknown 'quality, safety or efficacy are at present not able to be removed from the market. Other amendments in the bill include a provision to replace the Therapeutic Goods Administration trust account with the Therapeutic Goods Administration reserve, consistent with changes to be made by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1995 and related bills that will replace the Audit Act 1901. The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This is intended to ensure that technical and scientific data sought to be relied upon in connection with a general marketing application will be properly evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. One of the success stories of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 has been the orderly transfer of listable products-vitamin and minerals, homoeopathic, herbal and sunscreen preparations above SPF4-into the national regulatory scheme for therapeutic goods. Since the MC782 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 commencement of the legislation on 15 February 1991 some 14,000 listed drug products have been placed on the Australian register of therapeutic goods, and are currently being added to at the rate of some 2,000 per annum. This very strong demand for listing new products on the Australian register of therapeutic goods reflects the keen interest in the community in having access to safe and well manufactured alternative medicines, and the expectation is that the present very high level of product applications will continue. The impact on the Therapeutic Goods Administration of the very high number of product applications has been substantial, with the average approval times for individual products averaging five months-well in excess of the initial target of 30 days. To address this problem, the government provided $0.775 million in the 1994-95 budget for the development of a new streamlined process for listing products on the Australian register of therapeutic goods which would cut product approval time to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products. The new process makes absolutely no changes to the policy on listed products but does provide a fully automated document lodgement and assessment process, which will be available to industry from 1 July 1995. The new electronic lodgement facility and all supporting documentation have been developed through a steering committee with membership drawn from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the three affected industry organisations and the Consumer Health Forum. The new accelerated listing process continues the pre-market assessment of applications which is one of the central planks of the national regulatory scheme. Responsibility for making the assessment will be vested in the applicant, who will be able to undertake the assessment against published criteria and documentation and submit an application in a form which is electronically compatible with the Australian register of therapeutic goods database. Applications are to be accompanied by a certificate that the goods are eligible for listing, are safe for the purposes for which they are to be used, their presentation is acceptable, they conform to standards and have been manufactured by an appropriately licensed manufacturer in Australia. Goods which are manufactured outside Australia will still require TGA approval of the manufacturer before a listing application can be made. Lodgment of an electronic application under the accelerated listing process is expected to be able to reduce the time frame for product approval from an average of five months to approximately two weeks. Subsequent to the approval, the TGA will carry out a 100 per cent audit of product eligibility, both in terms of formulations and claims made, and will subsequently undertake a random audit of applications which are lodged annually for listing on the Australian register of therapeutic goods. The accelerated listing process will meet the requirements of industry for certainty in terms of product launches, whilst maintaining the existing high level of surveillance of product quality and safety. In the event that the TGA surveillance demonstrates that certification by a sponsor was false, then provision is included in the bill for cancellation to be immediate on any safety related issues but, in other circumstances-for example, less serious label errors-sponsors would have the opportunity to make a submission before any decision is taken to proceed to cancel the product. Any decision by the TGA to cancel the product listing is subject to appeal to the minister and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A new provision, section 19A, has been included in the act to provide the government with the means to deal with acute shortages of drugs supplied in Australia or that no longer are supplied here by their sponsors, or to temporarily allow into the Australian market a drug that Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC783 is not available in Australia but is required to address an emergency. The act as it stands allows individual patients to access unapproved drugs in limited circumstances. This entails prescribers to gain individual permission for each patient from Canberra, or for a prescriber to seek the status of an authorised prescriber under the special access scheme. Although both of these schemes are used with advantage to permit the supply of small volumes of unregistered drugs, they are too unwieldy and too slow to make available substitute drugs, or new drugs, on a larger scale to meet an unforeseen emergency or to permit interim supply of a product registered overseas during the period of evaluation in Australia. There are a number of reasons why approval may be sought and granted for supply of drugs under this provision. For example, a company may find itself out of stock of a particular product and wish to supply the same product as registered in the United States or Canada. Recently, there has been a shortage in Australia of lithium drugs used in the treatment of mental illness. It has proved very difficult to obtain a substitute product from an overseas source because of the requirement to have the product registered prior to supply in Australia. Companies who have the product have been understandably unwilling to go to the trouble and expense of registration as a stop-gap measure. Although vast improvements have been made in the approval time for new drugs in Australia, it remains inevitable that companies will register their drugs in America or Europe prior to introduction into Australia and that Australian patients and their doctors may have to wait until a company applies to register a drug in Australia. Provided that an application is in place in Australia and that the drug is deemed to have a unique therapeutic potential by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, it is proposed to permit limited supply on the basis of one or more overseas approvals. In this context, Australia has a number of arrangements in place for the interchange of information with reputable drug regulatory agencies around the world. These include the United States, Canada, Sweden, the United Kingdom and New Zealand. Through its membership of the PER-that is, the pharmaceutical evaluation reportsscheme, Australia is in a position to deal with most European agencies and with South Africa. The emergence of new diseases, new treatments and medical emergencies may mandate the supply of unregistered medicines as an emergency measure. Such an occasion might be the need to immunise a large number of people against a tropical disease with a vaccine held in insufficient quantities in Australia. If such a vaccine is not registered in Australia, supply is presently cumbersome requiring individual approval from Canberra. The safety measures to be put in place will include resorting to temporary approval under section 19A when no registered substitute produce is available. Furthermore, delegations under this section are to be limited to the national manager of the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the head of the drug safety and evaluation branch. Restrictions and conditions relating to the supply of such substitute products may be imposed to ensure that this provision cannot be used to avoid the process of drug evaluation and registration in Australia. The interface between food and drugs has been a source of considerable confusion since the commencement of the Therapeutic Goods Act in 1991. The existing definition of 'therapeutic goods' excludes 'food' but, in the absence of a definition of what constituted 'food', claims have been made, for example, that: skin treatment products that 'nourish' the skin are a food and therefore not a therapeutic good, MC 784 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 . gelatine is a food therefore products-including drugs-in gelatine capsules are not therapeutic goods. . These examples demonstrate the legal complexity involved in enforcement action through the courts, in the absence of a clear definition of what constitutes a food for the purposes of the Therapeutic Goods Act of 1989. Detailed discussions have been held between representatives of the National Food Authority, the Therapeutic Goods Administration, state and territory health agencies, and with the food and pharmaceutical industries, aimed at clarifying the food-drug interface. The outcome of these negotiations was agreement to introduce a definition of 'food' into the Therapeutic Goods Act which made it quite clearand Health be granted an extension of time. those in favour say aye, on the contrary no. Strictly speaking, the agreement to this unresolved question is not necessarily required, but given that this is the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health and is an important speech, I seek guidance from the parliamentary secretary as to whether he would conclude his remarks at a later stage or wishes to insist on this extension of time. sure that the parliamentary secretary is even going to finish it in another 10 minutes. I wanted to say a few words on that point. The honourable member for Herbert did not seem very keen on that, so I was not keen to be very cooperative, but I will withdraw my opposition if that would help you. cooperation. Extension of time granted. would have thought the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) would be very interested to hear what the government has to say about every section. However, let us continue. I was referring to these very important negotiations between the National Food Authority, the Therapeutic Goods Administration, state and territory health agencies, and the food and pharmaceutical industries, which were aimed at clarifying the food-drug interface. The outcome of these negotiations was agreement to introduce a definition of 'food' into the Therapeutic Goods Act which made it quite clear that decisions on what constituted a food or a therapeutic good were closely linked to its presentation and promotion and that a food could not be

speaker: Dr Theophanous
theText: This is a very important bill, with many different sections to it. IWednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 785 restricted by any specific dosage limit. The words 'prescribed dose' and 'frequency of administration' have been included in the definition of 'food' and are to be read in a pharmaceutical Sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages. The existing legislation has an anomaly in that it contains provision for a product to be removed from the market if it is cancelled from the Australian register of therapeutic goods, but has no similar provision for removing from the market illegal therapeutic goods that were never included in the register, whose quality, safety and efficacy are unknown. Where such products are detected and action is taken against sponsors, there is no existing basis whereby these products can be removed from the market pending either prosecution or submission of an application to the Therapeutic Goods Administration for inclusion of the product on the Australian register of therapeutic goods. Provision has therefore been included in the bill to enable the secretary to require persons to take steps to recover from the market any illegal therapeutic goods or to inform the public in a specified manner, and within a reasonable time frame, that the product has not been reviewed for quality, safety or efficacy by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. Decisions of the secretary in this matter are appealable to the minister and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The bill also proposes to redraft the main offence provision in the legislation, which currently provides that offences of import, export, manufacture or supply of goods in Australia are committed by a person who is the sponsor of therapeutic goods. The definition of sponsor does not, however, include a person who exports, imports, manufactures or arranges for the export, import or manufacture of goods on behalf of another person who is a resident of, or carrying on business in, Australia. The effect of the current provision is that the TGA must undertake intrusive investigations into the business affairs of persons that still fail to establish who the sponsor of the goods is, precluding any proceedings from being instituted to deter or prevent theÂ· unlawful supply of unapproved and sometimes dangerous therapeutic goods. The bill proposes to clear away the need for such investigations into matters that can best be established by those in possession of facts best known to themselves, the sponsors, by establishing that the offence of import, export, manufacture or supply of goods in Australia for use in humans is committed by a person, and by including a statutory defence for the person to demonstrate that he was not the sponsor of the goods at the time the offence was committed. This arrangement will protect the innocent agent from prosecution, and remove from the TGA the requirement to undertake extensive investigations into the business affairs of persons who are simply acting as the agents for product .sponsors. The act currently contains provisions for entry, search, inspection, sampling and seizure in relation to premises of sponsors, manufacturers and other premises for the purpose of monitoring compliance with the act, ensuring compliance with standards (GMP audits and postmarket surveillance) and gathering evidence of offences committed against the act. These provisions are restricted to authorised persons, are provided for both with and without warrant, and are spread across a number of sections and subsections contained within parts 3 (sponsors), 4 (manufacturers) and 6 (any premises) of the act. The bill proposes to consolidate these provisions into a new part 5A entitled 'Entry, searches and warrants', the existing powers have been reviewed and the provisions have been redrafted to bring them into line with the current MC 786 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 legal policy cited in part lAA of the Crimes Act 1914, which was inserted by the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994. The bill now makes it quite clear that entry without warrant to the premises of sponsors and manufacturers cannot be exercised at residential premises unless the sponsor or manufacturer uses the premises for commercial purposes in relation to therapeutic goods as well as a residence. The bill also introduces a power of entry to enable authorised persons to enter premises where it is necessary to do so in the interests of public health so as to avoid an imminent risk of death, serious illness or serious injury. This provision is sought to enable, for example, the prevention of extremely dangerous products from entering the market (in the case, say, of toxic contamination); or the halting of dangerous manufacturing process (in the case, say, of a clandestine laboratory utilising volatile chemicals). The bill also proposes that a number of indictable offence provisions in the act be reduced to summary offences. Since the inception of the act, experience has shown that these matters can be more appropriately dealt with by a court of summary jurisdiction rather than through the much more lengthy trial process. This change will convenience both the Crown and the accused as well as the judicial system. The act currently contains forfeiture upon conviction provisions in relation to illicit goods. This provision currently applies only to summary offences. The bill proposes that the illicit goods, the subject of indictable conviction, also be forfeitable. The amendments detailed in this bill largely address process and safety: the process by which drug products supplied in Australia are listed on the ARTG, as well as providing a basis for distinguishing between foods and drug products, and safety, in providing a mechanism to remove products of unknown quality, safety and efficacy from the market. The bill also reviews and consolidates the enforcement provisions under the Therapeutic Goods Act, and brings them into line with the most recent Commonwealth policy in this area. As such, the bill will substantially assist the sponsors of listable drug products in getting good quality and well manufactured medicines onto the market in a short time frame, whilst improving the ability of the Therapeutic Goods Administration to protect the Australian public from substandard, unsafe or ineffective products. Other changes included in the bill are provisions to replace the Therapeutic Goods Administration trust account with a new reserve account, consistent with changes to be effected by the new financial management package, including the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 that will replace the Audit Act 1901. Section 45 of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 will establish a Therapeutic Goods Administration reserve and make provision for the annual appropriation of moneys into the reserve equal to the receipts identified under that section. Changes to the appeals procedure for the review of decision to register or not register therapeutic goods under section 25 of the act have also been included in item 148. These changes are designed to encourage applicants for general marketing of registrable therapeutic goods to provide all relevant scientific and technical data to the secretary before a decision on registration is made under section 25 of the act and to ensure that any new technical and scientific material not previously before the secretary will undergo proper evaluation before a decision on review based upon merits is made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC787 Mr Deputy Speaker, this comprehensive bill is recommend and I commend it to the House. opposition spokesperson for agreeing to an extension of time. It is important for the government that the second reading speech does include the government's position on these things. As all members know, that can be taken into account if any of these matters are dealt with in court in the future. I might say to the departmental people present that they might take account of the fact that it is necessary to tailor these speeches to half an hour in future and the government should not be put into a position where we have to seek the indulgence of the opposition for the government's position to be put on the record. I thank the Main Committee. Dr WOOLDRIDGE (Chisholm) (10.43 a.m.)-I enjoyed listening to my friend and colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous). It reminded me of a story the former honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock, used to tell. When he followed Bob Menzies, he put a lot of work into his maiden speech. Before he gave it, he rang Bob Menzies and said, 'Would you have a look at my maiden speech?' So he went around to Haverbrack Avenue and Bob said, 'Leave it on the table. Come back in a week.' He went back in a week and said, 'What did you think of it?' Bob said, 'It is a very good speech, but too long.' He said, 'What do I do?' Bob said, 'Cut out half.' Andrew said, 'How do I do that?' Bob said, 'It doesn't matter. Cut out either half. It won't make any difference.' It is apparently a true story. I rise to speak on the first portfolio under the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995. I hope calling it No.1 does not mean that it is the first of a number of omnibus bills to come through this year. There is no miscellaneous provisions bill here, no tidying up of an act here and there. This is an act with almost 150 different items which introduce substantial amendments to three acts: the Childcare Rebate Act, the National Health Act and Therapeutic Goods Act. Just how substantial the act is is shown by the length of the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech. I hope this sort of legislation is not something that will be copied too often. As the parliamentary secretary has pointed out, this bill amends six enactments: the Childcare Rebate Act 1993; the Health Insurance Act 1973; the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973; the National Health Act 1853; the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992; and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. My colleague the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) will have something to say about the Childcare Rebate Act. I will make some comments about the amendments to the other enactments. I will say, however, that I will not require as much time as the parliamentary secretary. This is essentially because the coalition, whilst being somewhat irritated at the way these amendments have been lumped together, does not oppose the provisions of the bill. It is noted that, in contrast with some other legislation that I have had to deal with of late, the government has consulted effectively with groups involved-the aged care industry, the therapeutic goods industry, the Attorney-General's Department and other interested parties-to ensure that the legislation reflects sound day-to-day practice. The results are some common sense approaches to commonly agreed problems. Before saying anything in particular about the proposed changes to the National Health Act and the Therapeutic Goods Act, I just say for the record that the proposed amendments to the other enactments covered by this bill are basically straightforward an<;l are, on the whole,
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Leo Mcleay (Watson)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I thank theMC788 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 cleaning up some definitional uncertainties. In respect of the National Health and Medical Research Council Act, for instance, these amendments will not affect the council's operations but will simply clarify the definition of health ministers by referring to their offices rather than membership of the Australian Health Ministers Conference. I will say something briefly about the Health Insurance Commission Act amendments. We accept the government's assurance about the need to recast the commission's power to retain seized evidentiary material to ensure that its search and seizure powers are effective without intruding inordinately on the liberty of the citizen. Similarly, we do not oppose the proposed empowerment of the commission to engage in the hedging of investment transactions, although we notice that the commission would largely be exercising this power on behalf of Medibank Private. If the government believes that the commission, as the operator of Medibank Private in competition with other private health insurers, needs to have fund management powers consistent with its competitors, perhaps it will also admit that the commission's high level of infrastructure support actually gives Medibank Private a cost advantage over its competitors. Surely this cost advantage is one of the reasons why Medibank Private, as was reported in the Herald-Sun in Melbourne last weekend, is able to offer the best deals under the government's new legislation, while paring its reserves back to the statutory bone. Before leaving this act, I should say that I am somewhat ironically impressed that the Health Insurance Commission has the resources to spread its wings formally into the consultancy market. I hope that the new found entrepreneurial drive does not distract scarce taxpayer funded resources from the important primary role the commission has in the administration of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits schemes. Presumably, any consultancy fees will in some way be ploughed back into the commission's operations, thus reducing the Health Insurance Commission's need for recurrent Commonwealth funding. I now tum to the National Health Act amendments in relation to ministerial and regulatory powers relating to exempt bed status nursing homes. As honourable members will be aware, exempt bed status homes provide above normal standard accommodation and can share residents' direct fees for this level of service. They meet a growing demand for premium nursing home accommodation for those who are willing and able to pay for it. About six per cent of nursing home beds are now exempt, something the coalition in government may well look at boosting if there is a proven demand. As the government has pointed out, there is presently an anomaly relating to the compliance of exempt bed homes with the statutory outcome standards. That is, the act as presently worded does not enable the suspension of revocation of exempt bed status for those nursing homes which have failed to meet the outcome standards. This has attracted some attention as a result of an investigative report by the Age newspaper last year. If exempt beds provided at a direct cost to the user are going to be a viable and attractive alternative in residential aged care, users and their families must have full confidence that the product they are purchasing is of the highest possible quality. Therefore, we do not oppose the government's amendments to the act to ensure the power to revoke and suspend exempt status, especially since our understanding is that the amendments also protect the interests of those residents who may enter the home on a normally funded basis in a period of suspension or revocation of exempt status. If these people find themselves hit financially if they want to Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC789 stay in a home, or in an individual bed restored to exempt status, they should not be penalised unfairly. I also note that the aged care industry organisations support the government's intentions. Having said this, I must say that the solution to the problem is driven by the nature of our present centralised and bureaucratic funding and management of residential aged care. I have made no secret of the fact that I would like to see a greater role for industry peer review in the nursing homes standards monitoring process. It certainly does not mean a deregulation of nursing home standards, nor does it mean the federal government walks away from standardsit should not-but the present system is cumbersome and bureaucratic. I am also a little concerned that the inconsistent operation of the standards monitoring process around Australia may lead to unnecessary or premature imposition of suspension or revocation sanctions in some cases. We have had complaints of monitoring teams applying standards subjectively or unduly heavily, and I get the impression that different officers in different state branches of the Department of Human Services and Health themselves sometimes have varying interpretations of what is good practice against outcome standards and what is not. I note that any decision to suspend or revoke exempt bed status is reviewable internally and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I simply hope these changes will not mean an undue expansion in the use of the review processes and therefore the drawing off of scarce public resources in relation to these reviews. Finally, I want to comment briefly on the proposed amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act. We welcome these amendments, which will facilitate the more streamlined listing of many low risk listable products under the national regulatory scheme for therapeutic goods. I am impressed by the new combined self-assessment and electronic checking process to ensure that pre-market assessment of such therapeutic goods is as swift and cost efficient as possible. This represents savings to manufacturers and marketers, and it represents savings to government. Similarly, on the measures to deal with acute domestic shortages of drugs normally supplied in Australia, no longer supplied by an Australian sponsor or to allow temporary entry of the drugs still to be listed on the Australian register, provided that quality assurance exists-and I am assured this is the case-any reasonable freeing up of the importation requirements is a sensible step. I would urge the Therapeutic Goods Administration to monitor the operation of these and other liberalising measures in this bill to ensure that user and public safety is not being compromised by their operation. In terms of the prosecution, search and seizure amendments contained in this bill, I will certainly say they make sense to me. I welcome the amendments ensuring that the innocent sponsor of a suspect therapeutic good is not prosecuted for something where he or she was in all innocence party to import, export, manufacture or supply. I welcome the general recodification of the Therapeutic Goods Act's penal, investigative and seizure powers in a clearer and centralised form and the making clearer of the powers under warrant of TGA officers acting within the law. I am a little uneasy about the extension of the seizure period from 60 to 90 days, but I understand the importance in some cases of needing to undertake or commission detailed evaluation and scientific analysis of seized substances as part of the evidence gathering process. Finally, I also welcome the opening of an added opportunity to have expert consideration in listing application decisions incorporated into the loops of internal or Administrative Appeals Tribunal reviews of what are invariably highly complex technical data and related MC790 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 information. I believe that the government's hope is that this will discourage applicants from doing 'quick and nasty' listing applications with limited information available to the primary decision maker, in the hope of speeding up the process and reducing the need for review. I have to say, however, that in many ways we live in a 'quick and nasty' world where there will always be people who hope to manipulate the system for their advantage. While commending the government's intention and supporting it, I will wait and see what its actual effects will be over time. As I said at the outset, the coalition does not oppose this bill. We accept the need to take the steps outlined in it and we believe that, on paper at least, the changes implemented by these amendments will be for the better. Once again, though, I point out that in this bill there is material for at least three, and perhaps more, bills of real substance which would have better been taken separately rather than in this omnibus form. It certainly would have helped us get a quicker understanding of what these amendments are trying to achieve. Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995, I want to dwell on the second last item dealt with by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), and concentrate on one or two sentences of the changes that have been made to the Therapeutic Goods Act, which just shows how long the speech made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) could have been if he had dealt with it in great detail. One of the items refers to the temporary approval and supply of unevaluated drugs for use in Australia in limited circumstances, covering situations where there is a shortage of a registered drug in the Australian market or where a registered drug ceases to be available and there is no other equivalent registered product. I refer to a drug which has recently been very successfully used in Australia and emphasise the importance of the government accommodating its introduction. A range of illnesses under the broad definition of schizophrenia require a combination of drugs and psychological therapy. Until about 40 years ago it was almost impossible to find a satisfactory drug to deal with schizophrenia. People were hospitalised-I should say 'institutionalised' because one could hardly call them hospitals-and were seen in the grounds hugging themselves and rocking or extremely violent in padded cells, perhaps having been given electric shock therapy. Very rarely were the drug therapies successful, and psychological therapy on its own was not particularly successful. Schizophrenia covers a wide range of illnesses, but it is really an extreme form of what has been described by Dr Ainslie Meares as 'atavistic regression', regression to a primitive mode of thinking, which is an important facility in humans who seek relief from anxiety situations. Most of us get that: we are able to obtain regression to that primitive mode of thinking through a range of means, for instance, by listening to classical music for some. For others it might be sitting with a tinny in front of the footy, so the methods can vary a lot, although I must say that tests with students show that they study best using classical music, even if they think they do not like it. There are various ways of regressing to that primitive mode: relaxation is one; yoga is another. Having a holiday might be regression or even-I do not know that many do it now---:chopping the wood, digging the garden or feeding the chooks. These might be ways of getting away from it all, where one can regress to where the mind is not particularly active.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Snow (Eden
theText: Monaro) (10.54 a.m.)-In speaking on the Human Services and HealthWednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 791 Schizophrenia was seen by Dr Ainslie Meares as an extreme form of regressing and not being able to come back into life. In other words, the person regresses as a defence against what might be some very major trauma. The condition is manifested in a range of behaviours, such as totally unpredictable, violent behaviour and aggression, or there could be just a placid withdrawal-someone may appear to be superficially pleasant but behind it all have suicidal tendencies. He or she regresses to that primitive mode of thinking, does not come away from it and 'schizophrenia' is an all-embracing sort of definition. Clozapine has been used in Australia. The program at Woden has been available to people not only in the ACT but also to people in south-eastern New South Wales. The drug has had a great deal of success while on trial in Australia. A disease such as schizophrenia, which could be due to a genetic tendency, could be triggered, though, by trauma at home, at work or even, I believe, by smoking marijuana. So far, the drugs that have been used before Clozapine have been successful with a range of people who suffer from schizophrenia. Drugs such as Melleril, Largactil, fluphenazine, Anatensol and Modecate have very often been effective. But there were patients-some of them caught on the borderline of schizophrenia-for whom these drugs were not very effective at all. They had a number of side effects, without having particularly beneficial effects in treatment of the disease. Clozapine was found to have side effects too, particularly a granulocytosis. Woden Valley Hospital established a controlled program with Clozapine, where, after being hospitalised for some time, people were able to visit a therapist-first of all a pharmacist and then a nursing staffer was provided. Those patients were able to visit that therapist at required intervals. They were given blood tests and a range of other tests and discussed their experiences with the therapist. The dosage was adjusted appropriately on occasions when they returned to the therapeutic adviser. It was very often started at a high level and then reduced gradually. Clozapine has shown a very high level of success in a number of areas. First of all, people were able to return to the work force after, in some cases, many years absence. They were able to return to study, when they had not been able to study-at school perhaps-for years. There was a reduced tendency towards suicide, and those people could take a better part in society, socially and at home within the family. Paranoia was reduced in many of the patients. In a number of them, the anxiety level was stabilised. As with other medical treatments, people need to be balanced with their dosage in order to cope with life, but not to have so high a dosage as to protect them from the normal psychological trauma which we all suffer. That is the difficult time. When the dosage is being reduced the patient experiences some trauma. The patient, the therapist and the family have to decide whether that trauma is the sort of trauma we all suffer in life from the pressures that come to bear on us. That is the challenge when people are being stabilised on a drug like Clozapine. I believe Clozapine ought to be extended-and this is an aside-to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, so that it is available to patients on an authority, rather than, for instance, patients in Eden having to travel some 250 to 280 kilometres to Woden Valley Hospital to see their therapist regularly, and to get the supply from the hospital. Once the therapy has been stabilised, surely the patient's doctor should be able to obtain an authority in Eden and supply MC792 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 the medication with the concurrence of the psychiatrist who is in charge of the patient, so that this patient is able to receive drugs and perhaps attend less often. Attendances for drug supply, particularly at the beginning where there have been suicidal tendencies, need to be monitored very carefully. The amount of the drug given needs to be fairly limited. For that reason, any supply from the local pharmacist through a local doctor should be limited in quantity, especially at the beginning. Sometimes, if there are situations where patients are not being properly monitored, the general practitioner can at least ask those patients how they have been farIng and, if they do not turn up, can contact them. This is an extremely important drug, which is now available to people who have schizophrenia, who have had no success with other drugs and who have been continually returning to hospital for further treatment. The number of returns to hospitalisation has also been reduced by the use of Clozapine. The parliamentary secretary has shown tremendous interest,and his 'appointment and his interest have encouraged people in the health field. I would say to him that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme ought to include Clozapine, and I know that the evidence which has come to me from the people who run the scheme in Woden and which I am happy to supply would substantiate what I have been saying. . I commend the government on the bill as a whole. For instance, I have had people who havmade representations to me who have been excluded from the rebate scheme under the Childcare Rebate Act but who should be eligible for the rebate. Specifically, children over the age of 13 who have a disability or other special need which requires ongoing care have been mentioned, as have their carers under the age of 18 who possess certain child-care qualifications. I believe that this may involve a slight increase in expenditure. Of course, we actually included these people in the estimate for the rebate scheme and then-I believe, inadvertently-they were not able to take advantage of the scheme. That is important. It is also important for the government on behalf of the taxpayer to get away from the situation where people are getting double payments for child care through, for example, an agency or an employer. The changes that have been made to the new procedures, requiring the secretary of the department to give marketing approval for drugs, where the sponsor of the product certifies a list of matters that relate to the safety and quality of the goods, are important. Also important is the requirement for the sponsor of goods' that have been unlawfully supplied to inform the public that they were wrongly supplied and to take steps to recover any of the goods that have been distributed. I commend the bill to the House, and reiterate the importance of the ability of government, when it has a lot of information from overseas, to use the latest available be_neficial drug as the treatment of choice. Dr KEMP (Goldstein) (11.07 a.m.)-As previous members have pointed out, this bill is an omnibus bill containing amendments to various pieces of legislation in the human services and health portfolio. This morning, I want to deal with the amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. According to the explanatory memorandum on the bill, these amendments are being presented to ensure consistency with the government's intentions for the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme. ' The key amendments to the act provide hardship provisions to assist some people who are currently excluded from the chiid-care cash rebate, including children over the age of 13 who have a disability or other special need which requires ongoing child care, carers under 18 Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC793 possessing suitable child-care qualifications, and parents who are currently unable to have work related commitments. In addition, the amendments allow for the suspension of family and carer registrations if cancellation of registration is under consideration. This measure is to avoid unnecessary recoveries by the government, while not abrogating individuals' rights to appeal longer-term decisions, presuming that the appeal is not upheld and that financial adjustments by government may be necessary. Other amendments deal with a raft of issues, including backdating of carer registrations to the day the carer was first eligible to register; the cancellation of registrations due to administrative error; ensuring that rebates are not paid on child-care costs which are reimbursed by an employer; and other amendments of what is described as a clarifying nature. These include availability of the rebate for certain absences from care; backdating of family registration; eligibility of overseas students to claim the rebate; and correcting technical defects in the principal act which relate to recovery of overpayments. The range of amendments and of the issues which they address highlights a number of the shortcomings of the government's child-care cash rebate scheme and underlines the lack of certainty and stability in the government's child-care policies. The child-care cash rebate was originally targeted to parents who have children aged under 13 and who use child-care facilities outside the home while they work, seek work or are in education. It was expected that some 230,000 Australian families would make use of the scheme. The government allocated $152 million to the scheme in its first year of operation. Now, less than one year after it has come into operation, the government has realised that its original assessments were wrong. The estimate for child-care cash rebate expenditure has been scaled back by over $60 million to $90 million-a massiveunderspending on the rebate in its first year. The government, to my knowledge, has not been able to satisfactorily explain this extraordinarily large discrepancy between its initial assessments and the actual outcome. Of, course, there is a possibility that claims are being 'hoarded' by parents to be claimed in bulk at a later stage. If that is the case, it is possible that there will be a substantial blow-out in the estimates which have been provided in this year's budget. Around the same time as the child-care cash rebate was introduced, the government also introduced the home child-care allowance. This payment to those parents who choose to look after their children at home, rather than participate in the paid work force, was to provide-and I quote the words of the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) at the time: ... an independent source of income for women in unpaid employment in the home. It will not be income tested on family income. That was-as he usually does-putting the best light on things,because it was, of course, to be income tested, but to be income tested on the income of the principle carer. That was not highlighted in the Prime Minister's statement. The home child-care allowance was to replace the dependent spouse rebate and, as a payment direct to the primary care giver, recognised the unpaid work of women caring full-time for children. When the home child-care allowance was introduced, it was means tested, as I have said, on the income of the primary care giver. The promised $60 per fortnight was available to those care givers whose income was less than $10 per fortnight. Thereafter, the amount payable was reduced. This has impacted quite severely on low-income parents who may want to supplement their income by a small amount of part-time work. It is typical, really, of the way in which the government's child-care policies, including announcements made in the recent budget, have MC 794 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 impacted adversely on lower income people and the way in which one would have to say that the battlers in this society have been extraordinarily, gravely disadvantaged by the policies that are being pursued. The child-care area is just one example amongst these. The inequity between the child-care cash rebate and the home child-care allowance has been highlighted by the coalition since its inception. The child-care cash rebate is not means tested, while the home child-care allowance is. In addition, the rates of the two payments are quite different. A couple in paid employment seeking work or an education, with two children in formal care outside the home, can receive $61.20 per fortnight. A couple in which one partner works while the other stays at home to care for two children receives $30 per fortnight. It seems that, in the government's estimation, child care provided by parents is the least valued kind of child care in our society. The home child-care allowance was introduced while the dependent spouse rebate was still existing. It was subsequently found that many families were worse off under the new system than they had been under the dependent spouse rebate. It was only after protracted argument that the coalition was able to ensure that people who qualified for the dependent spouse rebate, but were ineligible for the home child-care allowance, would not have their financial assistance reduced. Like the child-care cash rebate, the home child-care allowance was conceived in a blaze of publicity and fanfare, was born in subterfuge, and is now about to be hidden out of sight inside the new parenting allowance. This bill evidences the same lack of foresight and planning in the implementation of the child-care cash rebate as did the debacle the Minister for Social Security presided over when the home child-care allowance was introduced. The range of issues dealt with by this bill indicates that the government's implementation of the child-care cash rebate was hurried, ill-conceived and, in many respects-some of which are acknowledged in this bill-unfair. One would have to say that the measures to backdate registrations and extend eligibility for the rebate look something like an attempt to show that the initial estimates of expenditure on the scheme were not as wrong as they currently appear to be. The amendments extending care to parents in the home looking after children with a disability are a response to concerns expressed by parents: concerns which should have been considered before the act was introduced into the parliament. In my capacity as shadow minister for family services, I had a number of calls from parents caring for children with disabilities who currently received the rebate but who, once the child turned 13, were then ineligible to continue to receive it. They were also ineligible for any other kind of assistance under any other program. This of course put them in quite serious circumstances. The government was prepared to leave these people on the scrap heap when this scheme was first introduced. The recent budget further confirmed the ad hoc nature of the decisions that the government makes in the child-care area. This lack of stability, lack of predictability, and continuing uncertainty for families, comes as one change after another is made by the government to its schemes. It leads to a situation where many people in the community, particularly those with less access to information and who find information rather harder to obtain, are disadvantaged by these continuing changes. The government has no strategy in this area. Decisions are made from year to year and, indeed, sometimes from month to month. It produces a high level of instability in the nature of the benefits, and in the terms and conditions on which they are Wed\nesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC795 provided. It means that many of those who would be entitled to these benefits never realise that tH-y are entitled because they simply cannot keep up with what is happening. In tl#s recent budget, the government mouthed its usual rhetoric of caring, while slashing outlays' on child care. It claws back about $330 million from the commitments made to child care la-t year. For example, while amending the Childcare Rebate Act to ensure consistency with the intentions of the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme, the government has restricted access to child-care assistance to parents not in the paid work force. This is a measure which will save the government $325 million in outlays over the next four years. The people who will be hit hardest by this reduction of more than $300 million in expenditure over the next few years will be the battling families in this society. The lower income families will be the ones who will have their access to child care restricted by these decisions. They will not be able to afford child care beyond the 12 hours for which they will be awarded child-care assistance. This figure of 12 hours is a totally arbitrary figure. It has been plucked out of the air. It is not part of any strategy to deal with child care. It has been put there solely to provide the government with large savings to make up for the extraordinary level of financial mismanagement which we have seen from this government in recent years. The government desperately needed to bring back something that looked to the public like balance so it has clawed several hundred million dollars out of the pockets of the poorer people in our society-the battlers in the Australian society. However, there is no hesitation in extending the un-means-tested child-care cash rebate. Much of the responsibility for providing these child-care places, provided for under the government's previous schemes, has fallen on private child-care centres. One of the consequences of the decisions which have been taken in the budget, as members of the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations said earlier this week, is to throw into doubt the jobs of thousands of child-care workers who previously were providing child care to the children of these battling families. So not only are families damaged by these decisions but the job prospects of thousands of child-care workers, according to the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, have now been put at risk by the budget. This bill really exemplifies the completely ad hoc nature of the government's approach to this whole child-care area. It is a matter which is causing increasing concern within the community as one decision after another makes child care less and less affordable for those people who have very little money in their pockets to spend. The coalition has consistently called for the development of child-care policies in full consultation with the whole range of different sectors of child care and not imposed by one group of interests on the other. It is quite clear that, instead of basing its policies-including the policies in this bill-on wide consultation, the government is simply looking at a series of short-term concerns and interests rather than giving families in Australia, and particularly the battling families, the opportunity to take advantage of policies within a settled and secure framework. Ill-conceived, poorly administered, ideologically driven policies and the lack of certainty and stability are having adverse impacts on poorer families in this community. This bill just further underlines the ad hoc nature of the decisions that are being made. Macarthur, I might point out that the bleepers that are allocated to honourable members are not meant to operate in this chamber. I recognise that the honourable member for Macarthur
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Andrew)
theText: BeforeI call the honourable member forMC796 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 I was doing all he could to silence his delinquent bleeper. At a time convenient to him, dmight be appropriate to raise with the sergeant the fact that his bleeper is doing more than bleepers are meant to do within these premises. They were actually beeping me to make sure that I was here. Obviously, there is something wrong with the cameras in here as well. This is actually my first speech in this chamber. I am very pleased to be here. In a sense, it is like a maiden speech all over again. I am pleased to speak in support of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995. This bill proposes amendments to a number of acts, including the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. As I said, this is my first speech in this chamber, the Main Committee, and I am pleased to be able to address my remarks today to two of my favourite policy areas, child care and health. The amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 are to ensure consistency with the intentions of the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme. Several amendments provide hardship provisions to assist certain groups of people who are currently excluded from the rebate scheme, but who should be eligible for the rebate. These groups include children over the age of 13 who have a disability or other special need which requires ongoing child care; carers under the age of 18 years who possess certain child-care qualifications; or parents who are currently unable to have work related commitments under section 39 because of extenuating circumstances. A number of administrative issues and technical errors in the drafting of the act also require amendments. For example, amendments are needed to make consequential changes to bring the act into line with other Commonwealth legislation such as the Migration Act 1958; to allow the delegation of powers by the managing director of the Health Insurance Commission; to allow the minister some discretion over receipting requirements; and to strengthen powers to recover overpayments of the rebate. The amendments will also allow the suspension of family and carer registrations if cancellation of registrations is being considered. This will avoid unnecessary recoveries by the government while ensuring that individuals maintain their right to appeal against long-term decisions. Further administrative amendments are proposed to allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the day on which they were first eligible to register; to cancel family and carer registrations which occurred due to administrative error; to ensure that the rebate is not paid for child-care costs which have been or will be reimbursed by another agent such as an employer; to clarify that the rebate is payable for child-care costs incurred for certain specified absences from care; to clarify the backdating of family registrations; to clarify the eligibility of overseas students to claim the rebate by amending the way courses of study are described; and to correct technical defects in the original act. Child care is one of the most important areas of social policy and economic policy that has been addressed by this Labor government. The number of government funded child-care places and the Commonwealth's commitment to child care have grown dramatically since the election of this government in 1983. In recognition of the increasing participation of women in the work force, the government has sought to provide quality, affordable child care through the various Commonwealth-state child-care agreements.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Haviland (Macarthur) (11.23 A.m.)
theText: I will certainly take those comments on board.Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC797 Child care is a very important area of social justice, which is why I think it is such an impOitant area. Because women are now quite rightly asserting their right to work, it becomes even more important. The lack of affordable, quality child care is indeed a barrier to many people, particularly women, who seek to enter the labour market. So that is why this Labor government sees that it is so important. Originally, child care was considered to be a welfare issue. To some extent, child care is still available for non-working parents through occasional care, but the main thrust of the federal government's children's services program is to do with employment related child care. The thrust is to provide access to the labour market for families with children so that one or both parents can access the work force. It is an economic need as well as a social justice issue. The priority of access guidelines in the child-care program ensure that priority is given to children whose parents are either working or seeking employment, and to groups with special needs. The federal government has been very active in promoting work based child care, where an employer provides child care either at the workplace or elsewhere. In my former employment I was very active in setting up work based child care in a federal department. That seems to have gone pretty well. There is more of a trend towards providing work related and work based child care. The child-care program has had some difficulties with some state governments. It was interesting to listen to the. previous speaker, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), criticising the government's child-care policies, saying that the government had had problems with its. child-care policies and it was all ideologically driven. I am very proud to be part of a government that does have policies, particularly policies which are based on the ideology of access and equity, enabling people to enter the work force. I think it is a fair comment that the opposition does not seem to have many policies on anything at the moment, particularly on child care. I think it is one of the last areas that members of the opposition should criticise the government on because it is, after all, this government that has done so much to provide child care forAustraIian families in the last 12 years. Notwithstanding that, we have had some difficulties with state governments. We have only got to look at the record for some of the conservative states to understand that the opposition is hardly in a position to criticise the government on policies like child care. Dr Theophanous interjectinggovernment-that is, the Kennett government-took 2Y2 years to sign the Commonwealth-state child-care agreerilent. It finally did so recently: Even worse than that, the previous New South Wales government did not sign the Commonwealth-state child-care agreement for 4Y2 years. This was despite the fact that the previous Premier seemed to have forgotten the fact that he had not signed it and actually claimed during the election campaign that he had signed it until it was pointed out to him that that was not true. I 1lm very pl-ased to say that within weeks of coming into power the Carr Labor government has indeed signed the Commonwealth-state child-care agreement. So now the families of New South Wales, particu1arly areas with young popUlations and fast growing populations, like my electorate, can finally get access to the affordable, quality child care that they should have after having had 'to waitJor nearly five years to access the places available under the Commonwealth-state child-care program. I do not think the opposition is in a very strong position to attack the government on child care of all things.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Haviland
theText: Of course, as the parliamentary secretary points out, the VictorianMC 798 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 The other area covered by the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) which I want to cover today relates to Medicare, and the enhancement of our universal health insurance system to provide access for all Australians to quality health care while at the same time keeping the costs of Medicare in check. The amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 correct a number of drafting errors and allow for the appointment as presidents of the Professional Services Review Tribunal of people who hold, or have held, judicial office in state and territory jurisdictions. This corrects an oversight in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 which, by not defining 'judicial office', by virtue of section 21 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 prevented the appointment of current and former judicial office holders in jurisdictions other than that of the Commonwealth. The amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act also enable the commission to retain evidential material seized pursuant to the execution of a search warrant until the reason for seizure no longer exists or until a decision is made not to use it as evidence. That is a very important area, also.
