I have spoken at least two or three times in the House on this sort of issue, particularly on the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Act when it was first debated and passed by the House of Representatives. That arose out of concern about the tendency of some doctors-a minority of doctors-to abuse Medicare through overservicing or excessive servicing, which has been a problem that has been around for some time. The Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Act has been the best attempt so far to address that, providing the Health Insurance Commission with enhanced powers and clearer legislation to be able to combat overservicing by medical practitioners. The first public acknowledgment of the extent of medical fraud and overservicing came to light in February 1982, when the then opposition health spokesperson, Dr Blewett, revealed some information that had come from the health department stating that the extent of abuse of the pre-Medicare health system was up to $100 million a year. That was for the 1980-81 financial year, and $100 million then represented about seven per cent of the total Commonwealth medical benefits and fund benefits paid under the previous health system, so that was obviously of some concern. . It was interesting that, shortly after that revelation, documents from the Department of Health verified that that was an accurate estimate based on the very complex computer system known as the fraud and overservicing detection system, or FODS. The AMA supported that estimate when its actuaries had had a look at it. In those days, before Medicare, when the AMA was not trying to beat the Labor government around the head about Medicare, it was quite happy to support that estimate as being a true reflection of the extent of abuse. That led to a Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry which was set up in February 1992 to inquire into medical fraud and overservicing. It is interesting that the chairman of the Public Accounts Committee at the time was the honourable member for Bradfield ( Mr Connolly). There was a rather amusing little article in the Sun-Herald a couple of weeks ago stating that the honourable member for Bradfield and I had more in common than people might have realised. Apart from the fact that we both lost preselection on the same day, he was the chair of the committee which set up that inquiry, and the inquiry ultimately led to administrative arrangements which ended up meaning that I had a new job, back in 1984. Also, I was involved in presenting submissions to that inquiry in 1984. Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC799 The Public Accounts Committee inquiry produced interim report No. 203 in December 1982, which was a fairly damning report on the administration by the Department of Health of the program which was supposed to curb abuses of the health insurance system as it was then. That resulted in the removal of the director-general of health and the resignation of the director in Victoria. Following hard on the heels of the Costigan report on tax avoidance, it was a fairly embarrassing report for the then Fraser government, which acted fairly quickly and put in some new administrative arrangements. They were put into place throughout 1983, after the election which changed the government. . In 1984, the Labor government introduced Medicare, which changed things dramatically in the health insurance system. It brought in the universal health insurance system which survives and, in fact, thrives today. It is indeed the best and fairest and most equitable health system that Australia has ever had and, I would suggest, one which other countries, including the United States, look at with some envy. As I mentioned before, the AMA tended to change its attitude towards these issues after Medicare came in, although it had opposed it at the time. I was working in the health department's surveillance investigation program then and we found that we were being undermined both from within the department, by some of the medicos who worked for the department, and also in the community. We were called 'Big Brother' and all sorts of other names because we were starting to have some effect with the help of the FODS computer system that I mentioned. We were starting to produce reports, although slowly, because computerisation and technology were not what they are today in terms of timely reports and things. But we were starting to show some results which were potentially very embarrassing to sections of the medical profession, so we were targeted. What ended up happening was that there was a huge political bunfight over Medicare, with the surgeons in New South Wales going on strike. Part of the way that the dispute over Medicare was resolved was that, at a hearing of the Public Accounts Committee on 27 March 1985, the minister announced that our function of combating medical fraud and overservicing would be taken over by the Health Insurance Commission. That was meant to resolve a political problem. It was an understandable decision, though one that a lot of my work colleagues at the time did not agree with, and the commission then assumed responsibility for the program. About seven years later, in late 1992, the Auditor-General's Audit report No. 17 was fairly scathing of the commission's work in this particular program. It suggested that the estimate of seven per cent of the total Medicare benefits as the level of abuse-which had been mentioned in 1982 and never really discredited, although a lot of people had tried to do socould still be valid at the time of that report, that is, in 1992. I mentioned in a speech on some health legislation in 1993 that, if it was still seven per cent, that would amount to over $300 million in 1992-93 terms. If it was still seven per cent today, it would be a lot more than that it would be more than $350 million a year. That is not to say, of course, that any government program that could possibly be put in place would ever recover $350 million. I am not suggesting that. That would be a bit like saying that if a million people a year broke the speed limit on the F5 freeway and were fined $150, you could recover $150 million. Of course, you would never catch all the people speeding, so you could never recover that much money. But I believe it is certainly an estimate of the level of abuse, although it is acknowledged that you could never possibly reduce that totally. MC 800 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 I think the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 is the best attempt so far by any government to put in place measures to deal with this very important issue. It is very important because, as good as Medicare is, and as much as I support Medicare, it does cost a lot of money. It now costs over $5 billion a year in medical benefits schedule payments alone. That is a lot of money out of the budget and we need to make sure that the costs do not escalate any more. There is a lot of pressure in the community for Medicare to cover other types of health care, such as dental consultations, chiropractic, and everything else. There is a pretty good social justice argument for it to cover those areas: why should the medical profession have a monopoly over coverage under Medicare? But if you look at the economics of it, there is no way, politically, that you could justify extending Medicare benefits. It would simply cost too much money and it would not be very popular to stick the Medicare levy up to five per cent or something like that; it just would not be politically tenable for anyone to do that. Therefore, it is even more important that measures be put in place to prevent abuses of Medicare so the integrity of Medicare is protected and everybody can benefit. This legislation and certainly these amendments are very important to ensure that the professional review tribunal can operate and can be effective. I am hopeful that it will be more effective than the previous system with the medical services committees of inquiry. They were never very effective. They took years to resolve cases and, considering the potential number of cases, they looked only at a small number. The new system should work a lot better and these amendments to the legislation are very important in that system. I am pleased to be able to speak on this bill and I commend it to the Main Committee. and to reaffirm that the coalition will not be opposing the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995.I want to comment on the previous speech made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mf Haviland) regarding child care. Most of my comments will address child-care issues. The honourable member mentioned that child care is not a welfare issue, that it is too important. In fact, that is a discriminatory comment because certain parts of child care are treated as welfare issues in Australia. The Labor Party only discovered child care at the last election. I will talk about that later. To recapitulate, the bill is an omnibus bill which covers the Childcare Rebate Act 1995, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953-which was a good year-and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. Most of the amendments proposed in this bill are lengthy but basically straightforward. I will be addressing my remarks exclusively to the child-care amendment and the whole issue of child care under this government and its departments. My research has come from discussions with a group in Western Australia called Choices for Family, particularly its Western Australian spokesperson Shelley Curry. I will use a lot of her words today. I am sure people realise that there are four topics which should not be discussed at a dinner party. The first is religion. We have argued over this since time began. It has caused numerous holy wars; there are a couple going on at the moment in the world. It is best to avoid talking about it because the debate might break out about the hypocrisy of the faithful or the true believers, or, as they are now called, the few believers. The other topic that should not be discussed at a dinner party is sex. It is not a topic to be talked about as people tuck into a hearty meal. People would also agree that politics is a no-no
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Richard Evans (Cowan) (11.42 A.m.)
theText: I join this debate to support my colleaguesWednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 801 topic for discussion at any dinner party. Lively debate normally follows any discussion on politics. Even the suggestion of the Prime Minister's name might bring forward colourful language. As I move into this particular field of endeavour, more and more I find that people either love or despise politicians, and usually despise is the case. However, I must comment that the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke is not controversial any more. I think everyone agrees about him these days. There is a fourth taboo topic that should not be discussed. If we were in the 1960s, it would probably be the Vietnam War. If we were in the 1970s, it would probably be nuclear energy. But we are in the 1990s. The taboo subject not to be discussed at dinner parties these days is child care. It can, of course, be discussed at great length, but only if the child-care situation of all the other guests at the dinner party has been tactfully sus sed out. Unfortunately, we have to work out where we stand on this very contentious issue before we can freely talk about it. It is a bit like politics: people either love it or hate it. The reason child care is so -ontentious these days is that it is, in fact, politics. Child-care is no longer a simple matter of deciding what best suits your family needs and aspirations. Child care is no longer a matter of choice. We now have to weigh up our desires as parents against a powerful system of carrots and sticks aimed at channelling parents into becoming two-income families. The Childcare Rebate Act is part of the process. Parents are subtly and not so subtly being told that, if they are at home with their children these days, they are just not cutting it. It appears that the business of nurturing a child is now some sort of hobby, that it is a pleasant way to spend one's leisure but not really worthwhile. This is the line being pushed by the Labor feminist lobby of recent times. Ms Eva Cox, the convener of the Women's Economic Think Tank, social policy analyst and spokesperson for the New South Wales Women's Electoral Lobby, recently stated on the ABC radio program the World Today: The people who benefit from having a woman at home is the man, not the community, not necessarily the children. I mean, it's very nice having time off with your kids . . . but it is not something which has a clear public benefit, it's a private benefit, and it ought to be seen as such. Ms Cox has lost touch with reality and has no concept of what it is to fully nurture a child, to have an interdependent relationship. Clearly she does not recognise that having children is something which does and should require adjustments to one's life and sacrifices of one's own desires to some degree. The men Ms Cox so scathingly sees as the beneficiaries in such a family arrangement, like most of the single-income families of today, sacrifice considerable wealth by agreeing to work as a team in partnership with their spouse and support the mother of their children at home. Apparently this point is totally disregarded by Ms Cox. And does the working mother always benefit? It seems all too often the working mother ends up under the strain of having two full-time jobs, all the while feeling torn between the two. Sure, working mothers may be a public benefit-Ms Cox probably thinks it is great for the affirmation of her feminist ideology-but at whose expense? Children are not a pleasant accessory to one's life. For most parents they become the focus of and the real purpose to their lives. Yet this attitude that parents share is continually derided by people like Ms Cox and those opposite pushing the same sort of line. I am sure honourable members are aware that these days many families are under pressure both financially and socially to have both parents in the paid work force. Now that the taxation assessment system for most families has no recognition whatsoever of the dependants being MC 802 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 supported by the wage earner in a single-income family, some families are doing it rather tough. The government has finally recognised this difficulty by introducing their latest bandaid, a one-off payment on the birth of one's child. It is just about enough to cover the extraordinary bill from the obstetrician, but then people are left on their own. Parents at home now receive the home child-care allowance, which is about to pass into history and be re-configured as the parenting allowance. The point I am trying to make is that the payment comes from the social security system and, therefore, could be interpreted as saying that families with a parent caring for children at home are a burden on the taxpayer. The government clearly agrees, because it calls the most natural child care 'welfare' as it pays it through the social security system. On the other hand, the Childcare Rebate Act allows double-income parents to receive childcare fee relief and, if their income exceeds the means test maximum, they can also receive the child-care cash rebate. This is considered by the government as an entitlement. The previous speaker alluded to that as well, saying that it is an entitlement for working parents but not an entitlement for single-income families, and that single-income families are welfare. Child care is considered a work-related expense by the government. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and her junior, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), were indignant in their defence of the payment, insisting it is quite different from welfare. It is a work-related expense, they say. It is also non-means tested. Assuming that it is a work-related expense, then surely the single-income family with a spouse caring for children at home should be considered a work-related expense. After all, if one spouse, usually the mother, did not give up paid employment to look after the children, surely the other spouse would have to. Maybe child care is not seen as a co-parental responsibility. Maybe it is seen as a woman-only responsibility by the government-it seems that could be the case-or maybe parental child care is not considered as legitimate as formal child care. I agree with the Choice for Families group when it says that child care is not a work related expense; and it seems the tax department agrees too. Child care is, in fact, a cost of having children. Whether parents relinquish an income to do this so-called work themselves or pay someone else to do it, it is a cost of having children. The cost is incurred because one has children that must be cared for. It is the very existence of children whose needs must be met that requires financial sacrifice. The choice as to how best to meet those needs should be made by families, not coerced by the government. The policies of the government, and legislation like the act we are amending today, are placing artificial divisions between families according to the decisions they are making in relation to child care and child rearing. I could have said that these families are making choices about child care, but for some families there is no real choice. For instance, if families are living in rural areas, there is no real choice about child care. If a family has a child with a disability, there is no real choice, although this amendment does address the eligibility for rebate for some of those families. If a family has a multiple birth, there is no real choice. If a family cannot survive on one income, there is no real choice. If parents believe that nurturing their own children is the only way to parent, then there really is no choice. Yet this government, so full of platitudes and rhetoric about families, appears to place greater value on the choice to become a two-income family. It seems that child rearing is only a legitimate occupation if one pays someone else to do it. If parents do this work themselves, then the time it takes, the energy and the skill all disappear, and such parents are seen by many Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 803 as being in a mindless state of dreaming along at home with no real work to do. The truth is that these parents are working at providing-with the love of a parent, which no centre can provide-all that is needed to nurture children. They are providing a safe environment, nutrients, stimulation, rest, life experience, opportunities for conceptual formation and, of vital importance, bonding: a long-term relationship of commitment to that particular child. It can be unglamorous work, requiring a hardy self-image and given no social recognition, yet many parents feel they must do it. They endure it because it is of a vital importance to them. Yet, for doing so, they are deemed non-working, and their contribution is totally disregarded by people like Ms Cox and those that determine Labor Party policy. Of course, there is an alternative to this. One can use paid child care. That is to be high quality care, and that should be so. We must surely provide the best care for our nation's children, because our children are our future. Support services are being put in place, and rightly so. There are well targeted subsidies and fee relief to assist families with the cost of child care, and rightly so. No-one argues against it. But there should be a balance. This provision should not be at the expense of those who provide child care at home. Support services should be balanced and equally provided to families who chose both paths or either path. Families that provide child care should not be treated as welfare recipients, and should be given the opportunity of lifting their status. They are treated as welfare recipients, yet they pay for the social security system. The child care debate is discriminating against those families that provide their own child care, and this should not be so. Government policies are creating nice little boxes for families, but the fact is that most families do not fit these nice little boxes. Many parents of families are neither fully at home nor fully in the work force. Child-care arrangements will always change as the child grows, yet the government does not seem to recognise this sort of diversity. For instance, parents who chose shift work in order to do their own child care get neither the parenting allowance nor the child-care cash rebate. Those that share a job miss out. In my electorate I have a couple of teachers who are parents and who share a job-one works two days and the other works three days-so they can look after their family. They miss out, while some on extremely high incomes get support. The issue of child care is complex and costly, and it is also discriminatory and entirely confusing. It is time we had a look at the way we provide support for families. We should be treating their welfare, in particular the welfare of children, as the real priority. It is time we developed an approach to family support that recognises the diversity of families without seeking to socially engineer their child-care choices, as this Labor government does and would have us do. It means that the government is really into social engineering. It brings these policies forward to get elected, and then it does not understand the ramifications of them. The future of our nation relies heavily on the health and well-being of our children. It is truly unfortunate that children do not figure too much in government legislation. Too often money does, but children do not. Too often the ALP tosses money at problems and hopes that solutions can be found; it does not actually go back to the core and prevent. It is clear in the matter of child care that the government has in fact got it wrong. I support the amendments to this bill, and I call for an urgent review into our nation's childcare policy and legislation. I give notice that I will be moving a motion, and in fact I will be writing to the chairman of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs asking for an MC 804 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 inquiry into child-care policy. If in fact this cannot be done in the term of this particular government, because an election is now due, I am sure that the Liberal Party will do it once we are in government. . The Liberal Party really is the party that is working for the family. In particular we are taking on board this child-care issue as one of the most important issues affecting the community. In fact, in marginal seats like mine I can say that it will be an issue at the next election. Unfortunately the Labor Party has not recognised this; it tries to discriminate between stay-at-home parents and working parents; it is trying to force parents back into the work force, and that is not good for their children. I will just give a little anecdote before I finish, Mr Deputy Speaker. The other day I went to a child-care centre. A three-month-old baby was lying in a pram by itself. There was a cold wind, but it was lying there goo-goo-gaaing and all that sort of stuff. I went over and stroked its face. It responded immediately; it wanted to touch, it wanted to play. This child was one of 15 children, some of whom were in a sandpit, which the child carer was looking after at the time. This three-months-old child has been at this child-care centre since it was six weeks old. Now this child really needs the parents' love, but the parents probably have to work, they probably have to in fact look to their income. What is causing these parents to work? Why are we not trying to help these children by allowing parents to stay at home? Parents staying at home are treated as though they are on welfare, and that is totally different. I support the amendments to this bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I look forward to a further discussion on child-care policy nationally. section of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) I would like to speak on relates to the Therapeutic Goods Act. On 18 December last year a constituent of mine Mr Maurice Czarniack was fined $96,000 for allegedly breaching the Therapeutic Goods Act. I am still of the belief that Mr Czarniack was victimised by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, with the full support of the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Mr Czarniack is an ordinary sort of a man. I do not mean that in a disparaging way; he is a very pleasant person, but he is just an ordinary small businessman, a pharmacist, who produced a mixture, amongst others, called 'Well Being Essiac Herbal Mist' which the Therapeutic Goods Administration apparently, at the request of larger pharmaceutical companies, deemed to be in breach of the Therapeutic Goods Act, despite it being made only of food products. I wrote to the then minister for health about this on 11 November 1993, 13 months before Mr Czarniack was charged. The day before that,ll federal police raided his house, his business and his mother's home, causing, as you can imagine, considerable stress to himself and his family. And all of this was because of an alleged breach of the TGA: 11 federal police raiding his business and his home. You would think the man was some kind of rabid terrorist. Mr Czarniack's argument was that his product only contained food products and, therefore, was not in breach of the TGA and did not fall within the definition of the TGA. This bill amends the TGA to include the definition of food, which has not previously been included. How such a definition would be interpreted by the courts in relation to Mr Czarniack's case I am not sure, but following the guilty verdict against Mr Czarniack in December last year
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cameron (Stirling) (11.58 A.m.)
theText: I will only be speaking briefly today, but theWednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 805 I issued a media statement calling for food to be included in the definition of the TGA. I therefore give this amendment my reserved support. Let me say at this stage that I am a cynic in relation to these particular creams and potions. Notwithstanding that, everyone must be treated as equal before the law. On this occasion I do not believe that Mr Czarniack was treated fairly at all. Mr Czarniack's products are all natural. I have actually seen him eat them; I do not know what they tasted like. In fact, the active ingredient is egg. Without egg, which apparently provides nutrients to the skin, his products are ineffective. Mr Czarniack was fined $96,000. Why was he fined that amount of money when the act did not define food? That is what his products were. The only thing was that, although Mr Czarniack ate it, the product was wiped onto the skin. At least that was what was suggested. Why, for his putting egg into his product, were Mr Czarniack's home, his pharmacy and his parents' home raided by 11 Federal Police officers? One of Mr Czarniack's biggest problems was that there were no secrecy provisions. He had invented a product, but if he registered it with the TGA it would reveal its contents. I am informed that a large pharmaceutical company lodged the complaint against Mr Czarniack simply because he was offering competition. Now a small businessman is $96,000 worse off. The other point worth noting is that, while the TGA rules that his products are therapeutic for the purposes of its act, the tax department views them as cosmetic so that it can hit him with a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax. Mr Czarniack was advancing to the stage of exporting his products. Now, because of a poorly drafted law, a minister acting at the behest of a large pharmaceutical company and the fear of those companies of competition, he is back to being a struggling small businessman. The Therapeutic Goods Administration stands condemned for its refusal to share intelligent dialogue with Mr Czarniack and, instead, hunting him to issue a massive fine of $96,000. I am not sure that these amendments would assist Mr Czarniack any more but I hope that highlighting this particular case brings to the government's attention the concerns of small inventors who have innocently gone about their business, have not mixed a chemical or lethal cocktail of any kind but have been harassed and abused by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. We might just remember that for one egg a constituent of mine was raided by 11 federal police and fined $96,000. That is appalling and it is also fairly stupid. The news last night had the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) looking at recent inventions. This is one invention the government has put the kybosh Â·on without any fair or logical reason. I trust that the government will consider such cases when looking at this legislation in the future. Dr THEOPHANOUS (Cal well-Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health) (12.03 p.m.)-in reply-I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and also the honourable members for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), Eden-Monaro( Mr Snow), Goldstein (Dr Kemp), Macarthur ( Mr Haviland), Stirling( Mr Cameron) and Cowan( Mr Richard Evans) for their contribution to this debate. AlsoI thank the shadow minister for health, the honourable member for Chisholm, for his overall endorsement of this package of much needed legislation. I note the shadow minister's comments about increased industry involvement in the aged care industry. On behalf of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) I spend a lot of time with nursing home proprietors and workers, opening various nursing homes and hostels all over the country, and most importantly with nursing home and hostel residents. MC 806 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 We believe that the correct arrangements are those that put the residents first, as they should be. The government is similarly concerned to protect the rights of consumers and to maintain confidence in the provision of nursing home care and especially personal care in nursing homes. Indeed, this is one of the clear aims of the amendments to the act. The outcome standards were developed as a direct result of wide consultation. The booklet Living in a nursing home, which was published in 1987, contained the material which subsequently led to the minister making standards under section 45D of the National Health Act 1953. The shadow minister mentioned several cases or accusations that the enforcement of outcome standards has been inconsistent and sometimes harsh. It is true that several complaints have been lodged with the Commonwealth Ombudsman. However, it should be pointed out that, up to this point, no such complaints have been upheld by the Ombudsman. Professor Braithwaite from the ANU reported on a study done into the reliability and validity of nursing home standards in 1991, on 50 standards monitoring team visits in New South Wales and Victoria, involving some 30 teams. In general terms, Professor Braithwaite found that outcome standards could be monitored both consistently and with validity. Some degree of inconsistency was found to have existed in the variation in the standards met between the states, but we are remedying that. In response to Professor Braithwaite's reports, the government has introduced a national consistency strategy to ensure variations are kept to a minimum. The strategy includes: national training for standards monitors; exchanges between monitors from different states; holding national standards workshops; compliance sheets and statements being selectively explained and reviewed between central and states offices; staff attending standard review days in different states; and maintenance and analysis of a database holding information on each visit to nursing homes and hostels, which allows analysis of textural justifications being given for reining in problem standards. These initiatives were positively acknowledged in Professor Braithwaite's 1993 report Raising the standards. I make those comments in response to the shadow minister's statement about consistency. In other words, we were already aware of this issue and have already acted on it, so he is a bit behind in his comments in relation to that matter. But I would hope that he would take on board what has already been done and what is being done. On the question of peer review, the government is not clear what the opposition actually means by the reference to peer review in relation to the regulation of outcome standards. On the one hand, the opposition states that it supports consumer confidence in the provision of care in nursing homes, yet when faced with the example of nursing homes where these standards are not met, it can only suggest that peer review will somehow remedy the situation. I want to just issue a warning about peer review. It is all very well to say that we should allow this industry, in a sense, to regulate itself. But it was found in other areas of government that, if we allow too much freedom in this area, we will end up with a situation where cases that should be controlled are not. That is one of the big issues. The opposition appears to be unaware of the present involvement of the nursing home industry in the review of standards. Each state and territory has a standards review panel which is set up under section 45E of the National Health Act 1953. These panels consider appeals from nursing home proprietors who are dissatisfied with the departmental assessments. Each panel has an industry representative, Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 807 together with a consumer representative. Accordingly, a significant level of peer review already exists, but, as I said, it has to be measured. I would like to tum now to the comments of the member for Goldstein. The government does have a policy, a strong commitment and a proud record in relation to child care. I thought it was quite extraordinary to hear him talking about ideologically driven policy on child care when he has been the representative for many years, both in the academic world and the political world, of the most ideologically driven philosophy that has occurred in this country and, indeed, in the whole of the Western world in the last 40 years. I am referring to the New Right, Thatcherite philosophy of which he has been one of the prominent spokespersons and one of the prominent supporters. So, coming from the member for Goldstein, that was a bit rich! But let me say very clearly: the government's policies in relation to child care are based on a comprehensive assessment of the way in which we need to meet needs of people-real needs, of real people. It is based on a philosophy, yes. But the philosophy is one that is generally accepted by the vast proportion of the Australian community, and I refer to the social justice principles. Those social justice principles are the very principles we have been trying to talk members of the opposition into ever since they went into opposition in 1983. They still seem incapable of understanding that the Australian community is committed to and interested in social justice principles. But, having said that, can we just give a few facts about child care? Since 1983, funded places have increased from 46,000 to over 250,000 as at December 1994. The government has made a commitment to meet demand for work related child care by 2001. Similarly, expenditure has increased from $65 million in 1992-93 to an estimated:-listen to this, Mr Deputy Speaker-$1.53 billion in 1998-99. Affordability of child care has also been enhanced by the introduction of child-care assistance and by extending the number of eligible families; the implementing of the child-care cash rebate which recognised child-care costs as a legitimate expense of working; and the implementation of quality improvement and accreditation. Having said all that, I wish to reiterate that the 1995 budget continues the government's commitment to families, with continued substantial growth in children's services programs that were approved and the targeting of the program for working families. The budget also recognises the need for occasional care by providing 12 hours per child per week for development sessions. The member for Goldstein tried to make this into a negative. Instead of a positive, he tried to make it into a negative. The further recognition of occasional child care was made into a negative. What an extraordinary statement from an opposition which wanted, prior to the last election, to cut billions of dollars off social programs and which now refuses to tell the people what it wants to do, refuses to state any policy because everyone knows that the moment it states its social policies it will involve substantial cuts in areas such as child care. I thought that the speech of the honourable member, given his record and his ideological predilections, was amazing. The rebate, of course, is part of the government's ongoing commitment to assist families with work related child care. The rebate is not means tested, consistent with the practice of not means testing the work-related concessions. At 29 May 1995, 244,000 families had registered for the cash rebate and 201,000 had claimed a rebate. New registrations are running at 2,000 a week. There is evidence that many families have not yet established a regular MC 808 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 claiming pattern, but we are hoping that they will do so. Amendments will address issues which have arisen since the establishment of the scheme in 1994 and will strengthen the rebate scheme. There is certainly nothing wrong with that. In response to the member for Cowan, the government's support for the child-care cash rebate is part of this government's continuing commitment to assist families with children. The rebate is part of a comprehensive package of assistance for families whatever their employment circumstances. These payments include family payments, current home child-care allowance and the new parenting allowance, maternity allowance and, 'Of course, child-care assistance. This package of payments responds to work force participation patterns which suggest that today most women will spend some time in the paid work force and some time at home caring for their children. The government believes that the policies in place ate appropriate and beneficial whilst offering a real choice for all women, whether at home or in the work force. . CanI also say that I am advised that the member for Stirling's claims are .not entirely accurate. The case he referred to is an emotive one and subject to much. publicity. Mr Czarniack has pursued his claims on appeal through all avenues. We, of course, encourage that and, where people have a just case, we look at it. I am not in a position to further comment on this case, but I can say that the government is always open to considering cases where there are allegations of injustice in the delivery of services. Mr Deputy Speaker, in your comments as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro you asked for the consideration of a particular drug involved in the treatment of various mental illnesses-I think it was Clozapine-and whether or not we can look into the question of the provision of that drug without people having to go to a hospital with a psychiatrist. Twill take up this matter with the minister and will respond to you at the appropriate time once I have a response from the minister. I want to thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate . .It pas been an important debate. I apologise that the second reading speech was so long but we had so many pieces of legislation to deal with. I commend the bill to the House and to the parliament. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Motion (by Dr Theophanous)-by leave-agreed to: That the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Consideration resumed from 29 March. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. The bill amends defence legislation for the following purposes: to enable senior acting appointments to be made at ministerial level rather than by the Governor General; to replace provisions under which officers hold their appointments at the Governor General's pleasure; to implement recommendations of the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review;
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Punch (Barton
theText: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel) (12.17 p.m.)-I move:Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 809 to extend the home loan assistance application deadline for a limited group of former members; and to ensure that the military superannuation and benefits scheme complies with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act. I will deal with these matters in tum. The first amendment will enable the appointment of officers to act as the Chief of the Defence Force, the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force or as the chief of staff of an arm of the Defence Force to be made by the minister rather than the Governor General. This will streamline the procedure and remove an unnecessary administrative burden on the Governor General. The second group of amendments concerns retirement and termination of appointments. At present the Defence Act, the Naval Defence Act and Air Force Regulations provide that officers hold their appointment at the Governor General's pleasure. Under the existing provisions, officers could be retired or have their appointments terminated at any time and on any grounds or for no grounds at all. The Defence Force is the last major Commonwealth career group subject to the concept of holding office at pleasure. This concept is no longer appropriate to a career service. The amendments to the Defence Act and the Naval Defence Act replace the current blanket provisions with provisions that specify the grounds on which an officer can be retired early or have an appointment terminated. The amendments also introduce specific procedures for the management initiated early retirement of officers and enable the promotion of senior officers on limited tenure where they accept a promotion on that condition. Corresponding amendments will be made to the Air Force Regulations. While these amendments will give the defence organisation management flexibility, they also increase the level of protection available to affected officers. Under the proposed provisions an officer could only be retired early or have an appointment terminated where one of the specified grounds is made out, or where the officer is subject to the management initiated early retirement procedures. Where appropriate, an officer to be retired early or have an appointment terminated would be given the reasons in writing for the proposed action and an opportunity to show cause why it should not proceed. The main exception would be where the period of fixed term appointment had expired, often referred to as a short service commission. Affected officers would also have the right to lodge an application for redress of grievance under the Defence Force Regulations and are entitled to submit a complaint with the Defence Force Ombudsman. Similar safeguards apply to the management initiated early retirement procedures. In addition, I emphasise that management initiated early retirement would only occur after all attempts to redeploy or retrain an affected officer had been exhausted and would be accompanied by the offer of a financial package. The third group of amendments is to the Defence Force Discipline Act, which provides a scheme of discipline for all members of the Defence Force. The legislation came into operation, provision was made for a board of review to review its operations after three years. The board found that the scheme was generally adequate but made a number of recommendations to enhance its operation. These proposed amendments to the act would achieve this and also bring the act into line with the Commonwealth Crimes Act provisions for the investigation of offences. Perhaps the key amendments are those which enable the appointment of discipline officers to deal with minor infringements of discipline. The board found that the present procedures MC810 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 for dealing with minor infractions are unnecessarily complex and administratively burdensome. A discipline officer will have the power to decide, with a minimum of formality, matters which do not have any element of criminality and to impose minor punishments. These will not carry the stigma of a criminal conviction. I should emphasise that the discipline officer will only be able to deal with uncontested matters and a person who wishes to defend the matter will have the right to a full hearing under the provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act. Where an accused person does wish to have the case handled by a discipline officer, there will be no entitlement to representation but the right to call evidence in mitigation of punishment will apply. Three new offences are created: unlawful discharge of a weapon, and refusal to submit to a medical examination or supply a specimen where a medical examination is being carried out as part of the investigation of a service offence. The latter offences will obviously assist the prosecution of offences involving drug abuse. The Defence Force has in place a firm no drugs policy and the maximum penalty for use and poss-ssion of cannabis is to be increased from a fine equivalent to seven days pay to a fine of 14 days pay for a first offence and dismissal from the Defence Force for a subsequent offence. Sentencing options for minor offences will be enhanced by introducing the punishment of extra drill, to a maximum of three hours spread over three days, increasing the maximum period of extra duties from three to seven days, and enabling suspension of the payment of all fines. Currently members of the Defence Force who are suspended from duty pending the investigation of an alleged offence or suspended while awaiting trial for a civil or criminal offence are entitled to payment of salary and allowances. This entitlement will be removed where a suspended member has been charged with an offence. Such a member will, however, be entitled to engage in employment outside the Defence Force during the period of suspension. These changes will parallel the provisions applying to the Australian Public Service. The remaining amendments to the Defence Force Discipline Act will streamline existing procedures for the conduct of investigations and hearings conducted by service tribunals and bring certain provisions in the act, such as those dealing with confessions, into line with current Commonwealth Crimes Act provisions. The bill also amends the Defence Force Home Loans Assistance Act to overcome a defect in the administration of the Defence Force home loans assistance scheme. In 1992 the act was amended to provide access to the home loans scheme to persons who first enlisted in the Defence Force after 14 May 1985 and were discharged because of a compensable disability before 15 May 1991, provided these persons applied for an entitlement certificate by 1 September 1994. While the changes to the act were publicised widely through service and ex-service channels at the time, it was nevertheless considered that the Commonwealth had a responsibility to attempt to contact every former member who might benefit and who might otherwise not become aware of the benefit. Unfortunately, some former members received late advice of the changes. As a result, some 17 applicants were debarred because the cut-off date of 1 September 1994 for lodging applications had already passed. Accordingly, the bill extends the time limit from 1 September to 1 December 1994, so that these persons will not be disadvantaged. Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 811 The final amendments made by the bill are to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act. This act establishes the current superannuation scheme for members of the Defence Force. The amendments will allow the military superannuation and benefits scheme to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, which provides for enhanced prudential supervision of superannuation funds. The amendments are of a technical nature and relate to the decision making powers and roles of the board of trustees and the minister. They are similar to amendments made last year to the superannuation legislation relating to Commonwealth civilian schemes. The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act requires, among other things, that the trustees of superannuation entities not be subject to direction by any person and that the approval of the trustees must be obtained for any change to the governing rules of the scheme. In the case of the military superannuation and benefits scheme, the governing rules would include the trust deed and regulations. The amendments remove the present requirement for the trustees to have regard to statements of government policy in exercising their functions, and provide that financial statements be in a form agreed between the board of trustees and the minister, and require the agreement of the board of trustees to any changes to the trust deed or the regulations. Honourable members will appreciate from my comments on the individual measures that this legislation is essentially part of the ongoing process of improving and modernising the administration of the Defence Force. With this in mind, I look forward to the House's support for the legislation. It is not expected to have a significant financial impact. I commend the bill to the House. Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, but I want to say a few things about it. In opening, there are two comments I would make regarding the procedures of this chamber. Firstly, I find it absolutely ridiculous that a member having been expelled from the other place and being responsible for this legislation-in this instance, the honourable member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey)-is not able to respond as he should to this measure this morning. be shown by members of the government to the House, including by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating). Had they shown respect, and did they show respect, I would treat the intervention with a little more good humour than I do. There is an aspect that members of the government need to recognise, and that is that attendance in this chamber is not counted as attendance in the main chamber. In other words, if you are present here in the Main Committee, even if you make a contribution-as Minister Punch, who has just made his second reading speech, has made his contribution here-but you do not at any time this day attend in the main chamber, then you will not be noted as being present in parliament. It therefore seems quite ridiculous to me that somebody who is not allowed to be in the main chamber is apparently not allowed to be here in the Main Committee, even though his presence here is not counted as his being present there. It is just one of those little things which strikes me as being slightly ridiculous.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (12.28 P.m.)
theText: The opposition does not oppose the Defence
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Dr Theophanous
theText: Ha, hal
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair
theText: It is the more anomalous because-and the gentleman might well laugh
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cleeland
theText: If he respected the House, he would not be
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair
theText: We could talk very happily about the degree to which respect needs toMC 812 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 The second point that I wanted to make is really quite significant. I know the honourable member for Moncrieff ( Mrs Sullivan) is on the Procedure Committee. It is important that ministers' second reading speeches, as we now know them, be made part of the first reading rather than the second reading process. I believe it would be very helpful, in most instances, for second reading speeches-such as that which the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel ( Mr Punch) has just given and which we are now about to consider-to in fact be presented at. the time of introduction of the legislation. There are several aspects to this, not the least being that, as all members are aware, the courts now take into account a minister's second reading speech in interpreting the context of a bill. So that there can be more informed debate, I think it is appropriate that that second reading speech become a first reading speech, and that time be allocated for that purpose in the main chamber-or here in the Main Committee if that is where it is being presented, as it is in this instance-so that there can be some knowledge of the purpose and content of the bill. I put those recommendations forward for serious consideration in matters unrelated to this particular debate. The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill is an interesting bill. I am always fascinated by ministerial rhetoric, so I was glad to hear that it is part of the government's 'ongoing process of improving and modernising the administration of the Defence Force'. Pardon me if I am slightly cynical about the degree to which that can be said to apply to these amendments. However, I will look at the bill in detail, and then come back and comment upon them. There are certainly aspects of the amendments which concern me. Indeed, I wonder whether it is not part of a wider political agenda which includes starving the Defence Force of funds in certain directions. I think that is quite seriously affecting the morale and good humour of those in uniform in a way which does not appeal to me, nor do I think it is for the nation's good. I am concerned about the extent to which some of these amendments do not seem to contribute towards the better management of the defence service, but contribute to the containment of blow-outs in expenditure and premature redundancy rather than anything else. As the minister has indicated, the package covers a number of other individual pieces of legislation in respect of the services. He identified the principal content of the bill. I want to go through each section. As I have said, in spite of my cynicism about the purpose of the legislation, the opposition will not be opposing it, although there are aspects of it about which I am concerned. I would like to get some response from the minister in due course, if I may. The changes with respect to the Military Superannuation Benefits Act no doubt make sense. They are in line with other changes. I certainly see no reason for them not to be approved. Similarly, the change to the deadline within the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act r makes sense. am appalled that apparently 17 people did not receive notice in time. I wonder how and why. In fact, in other circumstances individuals have had great difficulty in getting any response from the Defence Force on a number of issues. It concerns me that letters to the services are not replied to in time or are not replied to at all. I regard it as ordinary good practice in office administration to answer letters. I know of a number of instances where letters have not been answered by the Defence Force, and in this instance apparently 17 letters were not posted in time. Whatever the reason, it is not administratively efficient and, while it might be a bit of a leap, it strikes me that if people are incompetent in doing little things then they are not necessarily competent in doing big things. It is unfortunate that a change has to be made to legislation simply because these letters were Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC813 not posted in time to enable those applicants to take advantage of this particular change to the home loans assistance legislation. In any event, the opposition does not oppose the measure included within this bill to extend the time limit from 1 September to 1 December. Under the amendment of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, I am sure that all those who are serving are delighted to know that they will be able to get their punishment of extra drill to only a maximum of three hours spread over three days. I think that that sounds like a far more rational treatment than some that one can recall. I must admit that if one goes back to the days of Nelson, rum, sodomy and the lash it is significantly better. I am glad to know that at least in some things we have improved the lot of those in uniform. shown at times, my friend. That is part of the problem. My cynicism is based on experience of deteriorating morale and reduced capacity in training. We are having these new Collins class submarines built 'but I gather that at the very best we are going to be able to man three of them. It rather concerns me that the same applies to the PC3s, the long range maritime patrol aircraft; and to the FAI8s. I certainly do not think we are providing enough funds at the sharp end of the services to keep people trained. That is a bit of a diversion but the opposition does not oppose that part of the amendment. I notice in the minister's second reading speech a phrase that I just wanted to comment on. I would appreciate it if he could respond. He may not be able to do so at the. moment but I think it would be worth checking. In his second reading speech-and I did not check it in the bill-he says: ... members of the Defence Force who are suspended from duty pending the investigation of an alleged offence or suspended while awaiting trial for a civil or criminal offence are entitled to the payment of salary and allowances. Of course, this is to be removed. My concern is that that person should go through some type of a preliminary hearing before being denied payment. I do notsee.suspension in an arbitrary fashion as necessarily judging that person guilty. In the services as much as in the civilian community a person is considered innocent until proved gUilty. If there is an arbitrary suspension I do not believe a denial of payment of salary and allowances is appropriate. While I accept this form and I am not going to dispute it I think that some preliminary process to determine the suspension is appropriate. I do not know whether departmental people. have that kind of power over the uniformed services anyway but I think that a quasi-judicial process is very important-it might be a mini court-martial; it might be a matter of the officer responsible taking evidence-but there needs to be some process. If that person is denied salary and allowances it is also of concern to me that service people, because of the location of the particular facility where they are operating, might be a long way from employment. We all know the difficulties that spouses have in getting employment when they are transferred, for example, from Victoria to Queensland. A nurse or a teacher often finds it hard to even get registration in that state. If such people are going to be denied the continued pay and allowances, I do not know whether that includes their housing. So there are aspects to it which I think need to be looked at. It is arbitrary and quite different from provisions applying to the Australian Public Service. A. public servant is normally in a place for a lot longer in an environment where he or she and the spouse can work reasonably if there is work available. Such people are not entirely
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Punch
theText: What abo,ut when harsh National Party ministers were running the show?
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair
theText: I think that we have shown a little more care and concern than you haveMC 814 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 dependent upon the establishment but those in unifonn have problems of location and the availability of jobs. The way I read this measure at the moment it could be too arbitrary, and I have reservations about it for that reason. Above all, I think it essential that there be a preliminary hearing of a quasi-judicial nature which will ensure that there will be no arbitrary denial of natural justice to the person accused, nor a denial of that person's presumption of innocence, until such stage at least as there has been a consideration, because it is applying a penalty which in some instances could be extraordinarily severe. This is particularly so because many members of the defence forces really are denied the opportunity for both spouses to work; in other words, they are virtually in a single income family environment as distinct from the dual income that is now far more the common practice around Australia. So there are consequences of those changes which I think might well need review. I accept that they flow from recommendations of a committee. I know that there is the Defence Force Discipline Appeal Tribunal, but I am just a little concerned at those two aspects of it. If those matters cannot be answered now, I would appreciate the minister having a look at them-that is, a quasi-judicial hearing, and an assurance that people will not be unduly disadvantaged because of the fact that people in uniform are a long way from nonnal facilities. I will move on. We come then to replacing the existing provisions of the Defence Act under which officers hold their appointments at the Governor General's pleasure. I accept that there is certainly a reason to try to change from a system which really is perhaps a little antiquated and one which is certainly not appropriate to career service, using the minister's language. I am concerned, however, at several aspects of this change. The first amendment is designed to streamline procedure and remove an unnecessary administrative burden for the Governor General. I am worried about the degree to which, if we are going to make people subject to definable terms, the government will use this newly introduced, management-initiated early retirement as, as one serviceman put it to me, an alternative redundancy scheme, because that would certainly be totally unacceptable. It should not be an early redundancy scheme. I understand that there are problems which in part flow because the number of senior vacancies now available may not be as great: The changes to be introduced are perhaps directed more to that than to the reason given in the minister's second reading speech. But I do have a worry that, in the character of the legislative change, it could be that people will be prejudiced by not receiving what I would see as a normal progression of appointment. There are problems that flow, no doubt, from the limited opportunities for service at a senior officer level. I know many positions that were previously available for a person of a two-star rank are now being downgraded to a one-star rank, and of course one-star appointments are now reduced to a colonel equivalent. In good industrial relations practice, were these people members of the bureaucracy, I am not too sure that they would be very taken by this type of enforced, management-initiated early retirement. I know there are forms of redundancy and that it all sounds great when you put a few more descriptive phrases around it, but I am just a bit suspicious of the industrial good practice that this represents. I note what the minister said. I accept that the services are now career services in a form that perhaps some might have said they were once not, although I doubt that anybody who served in the past would see them in that way. I accept that there is Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 815 more management flexibility, but I am a little concerned about the way it is being introduced and the consequences of it. There are several aspects of this first amendment which enable the appointment of officers to act as Chief of the Defence Force, Vice-Chief of the Defence Force or as the chief of staff of an arm of the Defence Force to be made by a minister rather than the Governor General. I am very apprehensive about any change that removes the Executive Council right and responsibility. The Executive Council is largely an unknown body as far as most members of the public are concerned. It is a group that does not necessarily achieve the publicity that ministers attract. If a regulation is passed or a particular appointment is made, it is the inevitable consequence that people note-whatever is passed or the person appointed-rather than the procedure that enacts it. As all ministers are well aware, even attending Executive Council for some can be seen as something of a burden. But Executive Council is as important a part of our democratic system as cabinet or as any other facet of ministerial responsibility. Within Executive Council, where there always needs to be at least three persons present, it is possible for appointments to be questioned. It is possible for an entirely independent person, the Governor General, or, if he is not present, the Vice-President of the Executive Council, to pass judgment on the particular merit of a recommendation. As soon as you remove that power and make something subject to a minister's fiat then it creates a little bit of a difficulty. I say that because the minister, obviously, is going to have his prejudices. The minister may not be, with all the goodwill in the world, acting necessarily in what some would see as a dispassionate and independent way. I have long felt that appointments by the Executive Council have a great advantage. I note the minister's argument is that this change is going to: ... streamline the procedure and remove an unnecessary administrative burden on the Governor General However, I suggest that that is one of the reasons why we have Governors-General, to exercise that administrative burden, to act as the President of the Executive Council and to be able to provide a bit of dispassionate judgment. I know that those who are keen advocates of the republican cause might say, 'Well, it shouldn't be for a Governor General, it should be for a President.' Whatever the form of government there needs to be an executive council and the Executive Council is a group which can judge dispassionately a minister's recommendation. Under our system, sadly, more often than not there is more effective scrutiny at Executive Council level than there can be in the parliament. That is because so often decisions are taken at executive level which even the honourable member for McEwen( Mr Cleeland) may not be aware of. I know that there are not too many that the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) does not consult him on but there are probably a number of areas where I suspect that the Governor General might be advised to a greater degree. In those circumstances I suspect that it is advantageous to have an Executive Council determination. I accept the change and note that it is going to be by appointment by the minister. I know it is only an acting appointment-I know all those thingsbut it is the last straw on the camel's back. I have some reservations about it. MC 816 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 31 May 1995 I note also another aspect, another one of my concerns that has been there. for a while. It is now part of the system. It is the pecking order and the way it is listed that I am n.ot particularly happy about. You will note the order, and the minister has impeccably put. them in the correct order. He mentions: . .. the Chief of the Defence Force, the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force or as the chief of staff of a,n arm of the Defence Force In days gone by this is something that would have snuck in. A few years ago the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force was the most junior of the three stars in the services, and as far as I am concerned he still should be. As minister I pushed the joint service idea within the services and I still think it is the way to go. But there is a problem because of the way in which individual service chiefs are now relegated in the scheme of things behind the genÂ·eral dictates of wearing a purple uniform. I remain to be convinced that there is merit in promoting the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force to the exalted status of being No.2 in the pecking order. I believe he or she should still be behind the individual chiefs of the arms of the Defence Force, although I know that the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) and the honourable member for Moncrieff probably, like me, wait with interest for the day when we will have a woman in any one of those positions. No doubt the day will come. Because of the time, perhaps that might be a debate we could have on another occasion. There are several other aspects that I want to mention briefly. There is, with respect to the Defence Force Discipline Act, one other change which I did not address and that is the new offences created. Firstly, there is the offence of unlawful discharge of a weapon. I have no doubt that there have been a number of instances which have promoted that particular change, and I believe that change is desirable. Secondly, I wanted to address the offence of refusing to submit to a medical examination or supply a specimen. This is an interesting change. The question of the degree to which there is a capacity to be able to enforce the testing of people for AIDS in the ordinary civilian community is a matter of some public debate. I am one of those who believes that, given the consequences for the person providing professional health care, there is an advantage in having obligatory testing. I know that in this instance it is said to be because of the no drugs policy in the Defence Force, a policy which I totally endorse. This is a procedure and practice which really does have considerable merit in the assessment of whether or not a person is subject to AIDS, as much as to whether or not a person is subject to drugs. It worries me that in the community at large, health carers can be exposed unnecessarily to the possible consequences of treating people, simply because they are unaware that their patients may be subject to AIDS or to other highly contagious diseases. Indeed, Ebola, another one of those very contagious diseases which has been tragically apparent in Zaire recently, is something that we all note with horror and we trust it will never appear in Australia. That particular change to the legislation is important and is certainly to be endorsed. Before concluding my response to the legislation, there were two things that I really wanted to say. Firstly, I am concerned about the management initiated early retirement and limited tenure appointment conditions. I see them as being introduced not because of good management to the services, but because of the way in which manpower generally is being restricted within the defence vote, in order to acquire new equipment and to maintain a modem defence force. Nobody can deny that it is essential. Nobody can deny that, in the nature and character of trying to ensure that the ADF is able to meet any contingency, we should spend Wednesday, 31 May 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 817 a significant amount of money on re-equipment. My worry is that there also is a need to maintain a balance between the funds provided at the manpower and training end and the equipment end. I am not happy with the present situation in the services. There are a number of areas that need to be modified. I am one of those who remain to be convinced that the ready reserve is the way to go. I was taken by a speech made by a very distinguished former major-general in the Australian Defence Force, Mike Jeffery, only last week. He was talking of the extent to which we could commit those 3,700 regular soldiers who leave the army each year to a part-time commitment of seven days service annually for five years. I am impressed by the idea of utilising the skills of those who retire, particularly those who are still in an age bracket where they are can make a contribution. We need to use those people to a greater degree than we do now. I would like to see such a group being able to transfer into the reserves in a more appropriate way. Major General Jeffery talks of making them a territorial reserve. There is no doubt that we do have difficulties in being able to adequately defend the many facilities we have in this far-flung continent of ours. I suspect that reserves are the way in which we can best do that, rather than. utilising the members of the permanent forces. It is time that we looked at contingency planning, in order to better utilise the higher level of skill that is now apparent in everybody in the Defence Force. There is no doubt that, with the marked development of technology and the re-equipment, it is necessary to have a higher level of skill. That brings with it a consequently greater loss when the training, the experience and the education of a former member of the ADF goes back into the civilian force. Indeed, we are all conscious of the degree to which, for example, the civilian airlines for years have relied on the training of the RAAF to provide a constant regeneration of personnel for their new air fleets, and even for the maintenance of their existing air fleets. So the idea of looking for some way in which we can get better use of those who are retiring from the permanent forces is something that should be addressed. If we did that, and we provided more money so that we could better maintain the morale of people in the services, we would be a lot better off. When we start talking about management-initiated early retirement and limited tenure appointments, the consequences concern me. I think that both measures place a particular responsibility on the chiefs of the respective services: the navy, the army and the air force. Were this measure to be introduced in this form in the Australian Public Service, I think many people in the Public Service would be very sceptical. They would be worried about being given promotions to higher levels for temporary periods of time. It just does not work in civilian employment, or, if it works, it does not work to quite the same degree. I acknowledge that there have been a number of temporary appointments in the services, over the years. It has always been a practice of the system. But I am a little concerned about the way in which it is going to be played out. For that reason, I think that the success or otherwise of this measure is going to depend very much on the way in which it is administered. For that reason, the various chiefs of the defence forces will need to be very careful, as I am sure they will be. The opposition does not oppose the measures. But, as I say, I do have some particular reservations about some aspects of the legislation. Debate (on motion by Mr Cleeland) adjourned.
